movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A mournful poem about childhood and adulthood.
This is truly a film for both parents and children. I really can't find anything wrong with it. Not one thing. It's a beautiful and poignant experience.
Kubrick doesn't dumb it down or anything, but he's not actively trying to appeal only to film connoisseurs either. If any of his movies could be called mainstream, it's this one.
This movie has a humungous amount of problems, but I think that its absolute worst sin is that it'll make you think that the Jack Ketchum novel is some sort of Oprah's book of the month reject.
Yes, it's completely bonkers but that's what makes it so great.
This is an accessible art house horror film.

If you're tired of zombie films or rabid people films, Signal is like a cool drink of water on a hot day. It's got all the goodness from the best of those genres while creating its own niche at the same time.
It is an expertly executed slasher film done by someone who genuinely loves the genre and if you're a fan you'll enjoy it.
It's not perfect and will get on the nerves of the more opinionated critics out there, but it's such an insanely fun ride that most of its flaws are forgivable.
The first thirty minutes are quite good and the ending works very well, but there's an entire middle section which is badly paced and packed with filler.
A real shame.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Argo is director Ben Affleck's weakest effort by far, but still a well-made, performance-driven historical drama.
Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master is a challenging film, like most of his work. One that evokes a spellbinding performance out of Joaquin Phoenix.
Ben Lewin's The Sessions is an emotionally charged film with a smart sense of humor that'll have you tearing up from equal doses of laughter and drama.
Wreck-It Ralph is a highly original and exciting film that puts Disney Animation right up there with Pixar in terms of providing a story full of emotion, heart and energy.
Schindler's List is one of Steven Spielberg's most powerful films, capturing the tragedy and horror while still finding room to inspire and move generations.
Ang Lee's Life of Pi is a visual masterpiece, often transcending the boundaries of special effects and what they're capable of, but the film's actual story is hollow.
The Man with the Iron Fists is an off-balanced and bloated martial arts film that barely gets by on its gorgeous set design.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Hobbit may not be as memorable as the Lord of the Rings trilogy, but it's a mostly faithful adaptation that sticks to the same tones and themes of the source material.
Andrew Dominik's Killing Them Softly is a potent and miraculously-shot film that captures America's recent financial collapse through a criminal lens.
Kathryn Bigelow's Zero Dark Thirty is a grueling masterpiece that captures the hunt for bin Laden with a daunting amount of realism and efficiency.
Dan Bradley's Red Dawn does a fine job distancing itself from the original, but while doing so becomes a mostly mindless action picture with a rather shallow message.
Stephen Chbosky's The Perks of Being a Wallflower is one of the best coming-of-age stories I've seen in years, thanks to his enduring and truthful script.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Zemeckis boldly returns to live action with a soaring drama that exceeds expectations thanks to Denzel Washington's Oscar-nominated performance.
Quentin Tarantino's Django Unchained is a brilliant mixture of over-the-top violence and clever writing, making for the most entertaining film of 2012.
Martin McDonagh's Seven Psychopaths is a sharp piece of fun that both pokes at the current climate of filmmaking while also adding its own brand of humor to the mix.
Paranormal Activity 4 is the worst of the series and one of the worst horror films ever made. It's bloated, drawn-out and has no idea how to provide a single scare.
Lee Daniels' The Paperboy is a steamy, sweaty and trashy piece of cinema that rarely gets by on its filthy and wild performances.
David Ayer's End of Watch is an unflinching cop drama that uses the handheld approach to heighten the drama and escalate the tension.
Taken 2 is a pointless sequel that tries to capitalize on everything that worked in the first film, without actually including any of it.

Jay Roach's The Campaign can be funny at times, but it's mostly an exercise of patience as two usually funny men scrape the bottom of the barrel for some truly unfunny jokes. Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis have both been in much better films.
American Reunion is the worst slice of pie yet. All of the jokes are ten years too old and none of the serious dramatic turns amounts to anything.
Safe is an exceptional Jason Statham B-movie that managed to sneak through the cracks during its theatrical release.
In a world where we are either given silly comedies or serious dramas, Jonathan Levine manages to bring both together in perfect harmony for 50/50.
Ultimately, the film becomes an admirable, but flawed piece of work. The comedy bits work well, but the overall story leaves something to be desired.
Sam Mendes revitalizes the James Bond franchise with a slick and action-packed entry. Daniel Craig proves yet again why he's the best Bond yet.
Ruben Fleischer's Gangster Squad attempts to recreate mobster magic, but ends up fumbling into an endless amount of clichés and some horrid digital photography to boot.
The Raid: Redemption is simply the best action movie of the last decade. Director Gareth Evans films the combat with a trained eye to maximize the intensity and entertainment.
Juan Antonio Bayona's The Impossible is an emotional tale of hope and survival, shot with an unafraid eye for disaster and tragedy.
Gus Van Sant's Promised Land is an engaging performance-driven drama that works more often than not.
Zack Snyder's Man of Steel is a gritty and realistic take on one of the most iconic superheroes ever. It's visually astonishing and action-packed.
World War Z is a surprisingly entertaining, yet slightly generic zombie picture that shows promising scope and globe-trotting action, but suffers from too many genre cliches.
J.J. Abrams' Star Trek Into Darkness is a bigger and much louder sequel, which sacrifices brains and character building for expensive spectacle.
Now You See Me is a slick crime caper that works because of its witty dialogue & large cast, but falls flat due to a finale that fails to leave any sort of magical impression
Pain & Gain is Michael Bay's best film yet, fusing his high-octane and in-your-face directing style with pitch black comedy that makes for the funniest film of 2013.
The Great Gatsby is a visual treat & one worth the 3D surcharge, but feels like a lopsided endeavor that captures the style & energy, but not exactly the heart & soul
Joseph Kosinski's Oblivion is far from original and instead acts as yet another genre rip-off that looks shiny and expensive, but is hollow and lifeless where it counts
Derek Cianfrance's The Place Beyond the Pines is an epic film that towers high above the rest as the very best film of 2013.
Brian Helgeland's 42 is a serviceable biopic that graces over the serious drama in exchange for a quick emotional reactions.
Walter Hill's Bullet to the Head is a gritty and tough throwback to times when action films were simple, fun and still considered entertaining and worth the money.
Harmony Korine's Spring Breakers is rough around the edges, visually pleasing, experimental and a downright bizarre film, but one that's worthy of at least one viewing.
Pacific Rim is the perfect example of how to make an effective summer blockbuster. It has heart, brains and enough action and explosions to shock and awe just about anyone.
Upside Down is an interesting mess - coming across mostly as a visual disaster with big dreams and aspirations that never quite pan out.
Cloud Atlas is a mesmerizing piece of art that experimentally pushes the medium of film to daring new heights.
Christopher McQuarrie's Jack Reacher is that rare blend of hard-hitting action and smooth-talking dialogue that makes for an entertaining film.
The Last Stand is a fast-paced, action-heavy throwback, shot with a fluid visual eye by Kim Jee-Woon. Arnold Schwarzenegger is back and better than ever.
6 Souls is as boring as they come. It's a horror mystery with not a single second of suspense and a batch of uninteresting and naturally boring performances.
National Lampoon's Vacation is a comedic cross-country adventure like no other, thanks to Chevy Chase and the rest of the Griswold family.
Side Effects is a twisty pharmaceutical thriller that functions both as an effective drama and a social commentary on America's rising obsession with prescription drugs.
The Numbers Station is a cheap and predictable thriller that works only because of its two leading cast members: John Cusack and Malin Akerman.
A Good Day to Die Hard is the worst Die Hard yet; substituting loud, noisy and sloppily-filmed action for what used to be one of Bruce Willis' more entertaining roles.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Warm Bodies is a charming, fresh and always funny "zom-com" with a lot of heart, thanks to director Jonathan Levine's ability to explore love in the most unexpected of places.
Jack the Giant Slayer is a quick and simple action adventure that comes loaded with plenty of laughs and CGI spectacle.
Don Scardino's The Incredible Burt Wonderstone is a middling and extremely dated comedy that only gets by because of Jim Carrey's over-the-top performance.
Dark Skies is a slow-burn paranormal horror film that spends way too much time on setup and not enough on reveal.
Banished contains enough insights into race relations to be worth watching.
Polley manages it all nicely in her feature debut, confidently relying on the strength of her actors, but with a strong visual sense.
A series of conversations that are sometimes clever and sometimes feel like screenwriting exercises about the details of life, but are always well acted.
A stylish film that captures the bleak gloom of a desolate town and contrasts it with a satire of insurance commercials that concentrate on happy, sunny days -- not the ones that require insurance
Reitman is at his best when observing the state of debate in modern politics. He also gives the film a peppy, professional sheen. But he still has a lot to learn about storytelling.
Rogerson has crafted an emotionally satisfying exploration of the creative process through people who, before the program started, weren't comfortable with expressing themselves at all.
Director Yan Ting Yuen has made an odd combination of the documentary and musical genres that is worth seeing simply for its bizarre feel.
movie_title: Yang Ban Xi: The 8 ModelWorks (Yang Ban Xi, de 8 modelwerken) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Reveals a screenwriter who can write snappy one-liners and fill conversations with pop-culture references, but has yet to master story structure.

This immaculate filmmaking creates an engaging documentary that makes you forget that you're missing the energy of a live show because it's a completely cinematic experience with its own special energy.
With a little more sex and a little more comedy, this one could have really been something.
While the story does lightly touch on some of the questionable decisions of the Chicago Seven's leaders, it generates a compelling argument for free speech.
There's a lot of powerful footage in the film, revealing the startling simplicity with which many of the prisoners view their actions.
A dissonant mess, as frustratingly bad as it is boldly ambitious.
The style never makes enough of an impression to justify the complete disconnect it creates between the story and the viewer.

An extremely sincere depiction of the immigrant experience. Its core story isn't particularly better or worse than those of most other films about the immigrant experience, but it captures certain moments with gripping clarity.

Grace is Gone is a film that depends entirely on whether you feel empathy for its characters. Luckily, John Cusack's brilliant performance as Stan captures the experience of a newly bereaved husband whose wife dies while serving in Iraq.
The Island is an aimless and unconvincing parable masquerading as a Bergmanesque art film.
[Director] Temple succeeds in creating a portrait neither glowing nor damning, but representative of a remarkable man.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Boe and co-writer Knud Romer Jorgensen move what could have been a self-indulgent mess unpredictably as their star continues to lose his grasp on reality and find a way to make a satisfying story.
John Carney's direction is unassuming and without a hint of pretension, and his short screenplay lets the music do a lot of the talking.
It might not make sense at first, but it's about time the dark, seedy underworld of the detective noir was transferred to high school.
Game 6 fails to make use of its clever dialogue and concepts as it attempts to become something more profound.
A work that's deeper, funnier and more inventive than most indie films about young creative types lost in youthful exploits.

The story's surprises range from clever to annoying, but [director] DiCillo manages to hold it all together with his consistently amusing cast members, who make you laugh at their characters' self-absorbed folly.
Thorough and fascinating.
Leguizamo and Alcazar are riveting together.
The film goes beyond a nature movie with excellent photography and the determination of the animals it documents.
Full of off-kilter characters who don't talk like anyone in real life, but sound a truthful chord.
Murderball isn't a documentary played in the key of those Olympics stories that inspire you with sugary drivel, although it is ultimately inspiring.
It's a sure sign that a film is in trouble when the only character with any presence is a complete jerk.
Sanders inspires joy in life's redemption and anger towards the ludicrous ways some states treat the exonerated.
McLean has crafted a skillful thriller that will likely invade the minds many mainstream and cult horror fans.

Screenwriter Amy Fox, who expanded her 30-minute play of the same name into a feature film at the request of Merchant Ivory, shows a talent for creating multidimensional characters with both clear and intriguing motivations.
One of the most interesting and two-sided films to be made about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Unfortunately, the story of seductive and manipulated high school students tries to be a little too dark for its own good, focusing on its characters' evil qualities and ignoring any trace of humanity.
Dallaire's tragic story is a fascinating chapter in a sad history.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The slight characters combine with trite and pretentious symbolism to the point where the film is almost a parody of itself.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A dirty good time, a hilarious tragedy that paints smiles on the sad human condition.
A solid work of classical storytelling.
James uses his thoughtful observation to create a portrait of a family that sort of adapted and sort of refused to adapt to a new way of life.
Nothing is sadder than a child who has experienced tragedy, but no trap is easier to fall into than that of dwelling on a moping kid until the image loses its meaning.
Wagner achieves a certain intimacy that couldn't be captured with a camera present in a standard documentary, and couldn't be recreated by anyone other than a close relative.
The film is challenging and consistently interesting, but also trite and overbearing to the extent that it damages its message on gun violence.
Roos creates a slate of interesting characters who find themselves in unexpected situations that lead to realistic -- and in their own way, happy -- endings.

The art of the suburban-culture film has become paint-by-numbers filmmaking. Throw in some insane characters, medication and a little violence, and...voila, it's a dark and profound satire on the absurdity of modern life.
Nobody in the film is going to steal the audience's attention span.
A rewarding experience.
The documentary studies the different children at the school, some lazy, some brilliant, some sensitive. Argott traces their development.
The fascinating visuals and performances by Leung and the assortment of actresses like Gong, Zhang Ziyi and Maggie Cheung ensure that the film is still worth watching.
The movie makes the audience, like many of the other characters in the movie, simply want to get rid of her.
movie_title: The Forest for the Trees (Der Wald vor lauter Baumen) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This dark tale of societal comfort combines Allen's witty writing with the confusion and distress of making major life decisions.

While it might have taken [director Jennifer Fox] several years to figure out what to do, any intelligent audience could do it in 90 minutes. But even if it were shorter, it wouldn't improve the lazy filmmaking.
movie_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Director Jessica] Yu structures the stories in a manner that is not instantly understandable, but inspires attention with its profound puzzle.

The film oddly attempts to combine the backstage production footage with history-lesson segments. While skillfully crafted, the two stories never quite mesh, and neither go deep enough to work on their own.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Blackfish delivers ominous chills not because it documents orca whale attacks, but because it makes a clear, strong case that the attacks are of humankind's making. It's more Frankenstein than Jaws.
It's these uneasy shades of gray that make Noah such a compelling movie.
At it's best, this movie is pure fun. Those ignorant or forgetful of its predecessors might miss some references, but they won't have a problem enjoying its warmth, energy and humor.
The screenplay's exposition clunks along quite awkwardly, as characters find convenient reasons to spout out background information.
Life Itself may tell the story of a remarkable life, but it's at its most enlightening when dealing with death.

Director Lenny Abrahamson finds plenty of humor in his band of misfit characters, but the movie doesn't treat their odd behavior as mere fodder for slapstick. The movie's heart lies in its understanding of their fragility.
Tim Sutton's movie is a relaxed, contemplative meander through the city with this man and the people in his life.
God Help the Girl is like a pop song that is a bit unshapely and a little silly, but you can't get it out of your head.

The Zero Theorem is at its best when it's slyly comedic, mixing clever visual gags with its mysterious plot. When it pushes things, the tone becomes unstable, and the philosophical content falls short.
The creative elite of New York are always a prime target for satire -- so much money, yet so much malaise -- but they're rarely hit as mercilessly as in Alex Ross Perry's Listen Up Philip.
Payman Moaadi's performance in Camp X-Ray shines with enough humanity to illuminate the whole movie.
This film [is] one that must be seen again, if not to better understand it, then to remember the sweet feeling of reveling in its haze.
Sissako captures his story with poetic precision rather than gritty realism. Each shot is deliberately composed, and the transitions to new scenes follow a unique rhythm.
As breathtaking as Hard to Be a God often can be, it's a monotonous slog.

When your objective is to get nothing done, you have a serious advantage. If honesty isn't a priority, things get even easier. This is the most impactful -- and the most depressing -- takeaway of Robert Kenner's documentary.
The D Train introduces the most aggravating character imaginable, then forces you to spend 97 minutes with him.
It touches on real issues like student strikes and class disparity, but does so with whimsical flexibility and self-aware humor.
[Buckley's] visuals are both predictably bright and colorful, and his production design nails small-town charm as well as the odd world of Olympic gymnastics. Yet nothing ever really adds up.
As far as unconvincing arguments go, The Russian Woodpecker is as sleek as they come.
The most impressive aspect of The Wonders is that it manages to explore so many different themes without seeming disjointed.

If the filmmakers had an agenda besides studying Weiner's character, they did a great job of hiding it. Weiner shows many facets of his personality: He can be charming and funny, but he can also be a petulant, entitled jerk.
A Ghost Story rewards viewers who are willing to engage with it, to accept its evolving premise and experience the expressionless specter's afterlife as it reveals itself.
With a deep understanding of his characters, Green has crafted a film that's devastating and uplifting without sounding a false note.
Art and madness have always coexisted, but Camille Claudel, 1915 is about what happens when you take away the art and stifle a troubled, extraordinary mind.
It's not definitive, tidy or entirely cohesive, but hey, neither was the movement.
movie_title: 99%: The Occupy Wall Street Collaborative Film (2013)

movie_review_blurb: God's Pocket has all the ingredients of a mischievous black comedy, but is neither sly nor merciless enough to embrace the absurdity of its tragedy.
Part of Afternoon Delight wants to be a sitcom, and part wants to be a John Cassavetes film. That these two sides never find harmony is no surprise.
That anyone would allow this new guy into their lives is a complete stretch.
While at times the film begins to feel like a laundry list of bad deeds, the first-person accounts pack a wallop.
Even when the film goes off the rails, however, it's still a fun ride.
Rather than trying to beat Hollywood at its own game of high-tech gadgets and weaponry, director Colin Trevorrow and writer Derek Connolly achieve a sly mix of the insane and the mundane.
The Master studies its characters with such mystique, tragedy and humor that there's not a moment that isn't enthralling.
Simon and the Oaks is a lot of things, but above all, it is too much.
Far from a typical tale of alcoholism, Smashed tells a very specific -- and at times quite funny -- story with rich characters.
It's hard to determine exactly what Newlyweeds wants to accomplish, but it's plain to see that it fails.
Barbara takes place in a world of such profound paranoia that it's never certain whether the title character is being overly cautious or reckless.
The film features excellent singing, for the most part, but it also emphasizes fragility in a work that's largely defined by its grandiosity.

Hangups, regrets and doubts have have become a greater part of Jesse and Celine's lives, and the film reflects that. But it also reminds us what made the couple such a lovable pair that they could hold our interest for 20 years.
Heinzerling combines Noriko's drawings with contemporary footage to create a story that isn't only a tale of creative minds, but an honest love story.
Poor Rebecca Hall. If someone had told her there was no hope for Lay the Favorite, she could have saved some energy.
Upstream Color builds a stunning mosaic of lives overwhelmed by decisions outside their control, of people who don't understand the impulses that rule their lives.
Breathe In comes ever so close to pulling an emotionally satisfying romance from what is, at its core, a rather pervy story.
A Hijacking delivers all the thrills the title suggests, but in none of the places you'd expect them.
Hagen's performance shows an unblinking determination that makes every near-death moment more unpredictable.
Mud combines the poignance of a boy coming to terms with life's realities with the excitement of top-notch suspense.
It may never come close to what you've read, but you'll definitely see something new.
Those willing to drift along with it will find a compelling character study about a man coming to terms with himself, his son, and the people who enter their lives.
Despite the shortcomings of the interview, the film assembles a portrait of the man's life, eventually keying in on his time as vice president to George W. Bush.
movie_title: The World According to Dick Cheney (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Escape from Tomorrow isn't awful, but it's the kind of film that makes you wish it were better than it is.
We Are What We Are is a film that ought to feel like an amusement park terror ride, but instead comes off as a poor attempt at fine art.
This isn't a long film, but it lacks propulsion at times. Luckily, it maintains its wry outlook and never quite erases the good will that its best moments inspire.

Director James Ponsoldt has adapted Tim Tharp's coming-of-age novel with heartfelt sincerity, but the movie lacks a cutting bite to push it past innocuous teenage drama to a truly deep portrait of adolescence.
Welles comes off as an imperious, duplicitous, philandering brat. But he's also funny, seductive, and ingenious.
It's worth seeking out, standing as Lurie's best film work to date and a gentle reminder that Farmiga and Beckinsale are two talented, tough actresses in it for the long haul.
A Space Program: The Movie, and Sachs's work in general, is resourceful, cheeky, and fun.
Fascinating and oddly inspiring, Gored is too focused on Barrera the myth to ever really focus on Barrera the man.
Cheery and happily empty-headed, the present-day subplot adds little but sentiment to a film shot through with cliché characters, a predictable plot, and undisguised reverence.
Ted 2 also succeeds with the laughs but doesn't really provide anything to keep audiences emotionally invested.
Markridis has structured Pity as a slow burn, and this works just fine even though he tips his hand early.
Adolescence was always a minefield, but the present-day situation feels like the Normandy Invasion.
I ... walked out grinning, looking forward to the moment when I get to share this beautiful little movie with my friends.
Tamara Jenkins serves up hilariously uncomfortable moments like this throughout Private Life, and she never once pays them off in a conventionally satisfying manner.
A conventional yet wholly enjoyable journey through the life and filmography of the era's revered maverick.
All I can safely assert after one viewing is this: Decker and Howard are formidable talents, and Madeline's Madeline is a must for anyone who cares about the future of this medium.

Granik and her Winter's Bone writing partner Anne Rosselini have once again burrowed into the lives of the truly forgotten people of the United States, only this time they're without a marketable whodunit hook.
Riley may come on like a goofball, but at heart he's a brawler. He's not trying to skillfully outpoint his opponents; he's out there headhunting. He's also a ferociously talented filmmaker.
Now we get to wrestle with The King, a Rorschach test of a documentary that bombards the viewer with wildly conflicting takes on the meaning of Elvis Presley in American life.

Lee's certainly been a part of this dialogue for a long time, and it's thrilling to see him hook into turbulent material from a talented young writer eager to throw some dramatic haymakers of her own.
A conventionally raucous biopic that knows it's conventional and hopes to get away with said convention by occasionally breaking the fourth wall to goof on its deployment of these hoary tropes.
House at the End of the Street reveals itself to be merely another forgettable PG-13 thriller banking on the brain-dead mall crowd to tweet their unending love for a crummy feast such as this.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While Paranormal Activity 4 is a lesser film than its predecessors, it still delivers the shocking goods and ends with a frightening finale that promises much more to come.
The Revenant is legitimately funny, inventive, and just plain cool.
Fans of the series might be satisfied with what they find in the movie, but that doesn't mean that there aren't valid criticisms to be found in this lofty, yet meandering third outing.
The Amazing Spider-Man is one confused mixed bag of a superhero movie.
Deliberate in pace and haunting in nature.
Maybe what's most fresh about Defendor is the plausibility of it all.
Disquieting, lush in style, and most importantly, emotionally engaging, The Possession is a throwback to celebrated cinematic horror of old.

No matter what, it's safe to say that this entirely acceptable retooling of the franchise makes for a satisfying experience for those who enjoy four-wheeled chases, hot bodies, hot cars, and a tall dose of tough-guy machismo.
The picture is really missing that vampiric bite that it should have.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Questionable style aside, it does what it sets out to do -- entertain.
What will they do next? Probably rip more people off. It's worked for them so far.

Claustrophobic, jittery at times, and electric in pace, Quarantine is a stripped-down bloody thrill ride that -- while certainly not catering to everyone's tastes -- should satisfy gore-hounds looking to step up their theatrical horror cuisine.
Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol could very well be the series' best installment.
The Resident Evil films are not everyone's bag, although they seem to be evolving into their own brand of hyper-stylized cheese, made more extreme with each outing.
A superpowered crowd-pleaser, Marvel's The Avengers wows its way into comics-to-film history as one of the greatest popcorn flicks of its era.
James Bond embraces the Jason Bourne model with Quantum of Solace, a rough-and-tough 007 adventure whose aspirations are admirable, even if the aesthetics are not.
The good news for crummy-horror-movie fans is that there's a whole lot more fun in this one since it's dumber and shorter than the first entry.
This is it -- this is James Bond in all of his glory -- in what easily ranks up there with the best Bond films of them all.
The Red Dawn remake is as needless a reboot as Hollywood can offer.
Kung fu fans will be happy that Iron Fists exists and is just as entertaining as they hoped it would be.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While Dominik flourishes when it comes to the picture's excessive violence, he seems to be unable to balance those sequences with the drawn-out scenes of dialogue, which, while delivered nicely, kill any momentum the film might have had.
Villains rarely get the lead-character treatment in Hollywood, and that alone makes Chronicle worthy viewing if one is craving a unique found-footage film.
Director Craig Zobel delivers a hard-hitting and tense study of morality with Compliance, a menacing drama meant to provoke strong reactions and discussions after the credits roll.
Sadly, the picture is just too mild for its own good.
This found-footage spoof impresses right out of the gate, because in the first five minutes one sacred movie taboo is thrown out the window and pummeled to absolutely absurd lengths.
John McClane is easily one of the big screen's most beloved heroes, but retrofitting him with modern sensibilities just doesn't work.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: When the picture isn't ramping up your heart rate, it switches gears and becomes an intimate character study in what war does to humankind.
Devoid of scares and energy, the picture is all bumps in the night and has nothing to set it apart from its other forgettable post-Japanese horror contemporaries.

If you've seen your share of teenagers getting sliced and diced out in the boondocks, chances are you'll be tickled pink by this tale of a couple of good-natured bumpkins who are mistaken for serial murderers.

The Expendables 2 is a shot to the arm of pure, silly action-movie fun, and it stars so many heavy hitters it might break your brain to keep up with what's happening onscreen at various points during its slim 103-minute run time.
The success of The Disaster Artist is less a thoughtful almost-adaptation and more a testament to one man and his quest for greatness - even if it means being the worst of the best.
... Steven Rogers' (Hope Floats, P.S. I Love You) screenplay is masterful...
Tristram Shandy: A Cock and Bull Story is an eccentric hoot of a film, a delight for lovers of nattering British comedy. Or the business of moviemaking. Or just deadpan, postmodern silliness.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Nifty title, execrable film.
Judging by audience reaction -- out of their seats, in the aisles, standing up, swaying to the music, howling in recognition of material that hit home -- these kings rule.
Keep an eye on Lil Bow Wow, folks. If Like Mike is any indication, he's bound to score again.

About 45 minutes into the screening of Super Troopers I had my first laugh. Then, as the credits rolled, I had my second. The time in between those laughs went slower than an ant climbing Mount Saint Helens.
Spears may find her way as an actress, but Crossroads leads to a dead end.
Wrapped up in Tim Allen's new film, Joe Somebody, is a gem of a message. Unfortunately, the packaging isn't as good as the moral.
While not Oscar-worthy stuff, Not Another Teen Movie does make the laughter grade.
Is this a good movie? Surely, you jest.
Carey has a wonderful gift; it's just not in acting.
In the game of love there are winners and losers, but with this flick, we've all hit the jackpot.
Very few movies can make you laugh, cringe and feel dirty, all at the same time.
As close as these men say they are, the film makes it very difficult to believe they are friends.
The movie makes no apology for its extreme campiness at times, and it blatantly rips off other films.
Not a giggle, not a smile nor a smirk came out or across my face.
The moviemakers left the story line open for a sequel, but in this case, let's hope once is enough.
Audiences who appreciate extremely raunchy humor will find the giggles flowing, but remember to bring the tissue, because you'll laugh until you cry.
Undisputed is slow going at the beginning, and some scenes will leave you yawning. At least the fight sequences, the film's saving grace, are a knockout.
[Story] does a fine job of giving the audience the 'you are there' feel of being a patron in an African-American barbershop.
Despite the premise of a good story ... it wastes all its star power on cliched or meaningless roles.
Halle Berry's Catwoman is a dog. And no amount of tight black leather outfits, nauseating CGI effects and good-looking actors and actresses is going to change that.
A blatant rip-off of Eddie Murphy's The Golden Child from 1986.
You'll cringe in horror at the stinkfest on screen.
It's always great to see a good actress at work. With Disney's remake of 1976's Freaky Friday, audiences get to see two of them.
Has [Malkovich's] career really come to this?
Can this career be saved? After watching The Fighting Temptations, you may feel that Cuba Gooding Jr.'s may not.
Seems more like a voyage aboard the Titanic than a split-your -sides-laughing comedy.
A 90-minute movie that contains a really bad computer-generated kangaroo, some awful flatulence jokes and a horribly conceived plot.
Even a 4-year-old can spot very early on who will be wearing the title of Mrs. Claus, but the ride to matrimony is well worth the trip.
Harris is supposed to be the star of the story, but comes across as pretty dull and wooden.
As Winnie, Bledel does an excellent job capturing the longing of a teen on the verge of adulthood.
The writers may have figured The Tuxedo was tailor-made for a Chan/Hewitt pairing, but both may want to go back into the acting closet and pick out a film -- and a co-star -- that's a better fit.
Despite Chow's efforts, Monk has plot holes as big as the Grand Canyon, and the fight scenes only serve as a Band-Aid over a gaping wound.

It's a strange and subtly told tale that successfully hacks into the desires and fears of most us who are trying to figure out how to make love work -- without sewing it all back together into a nice, pretty package.
For those who've never seen Cuba up close, The Sugar Curtain offers an astonishing glimpse of the culture, one that's devoid of both the glamor and the manipulations of mainstream media.
movie_title: The Sugar Curtain (El Telon de azucar) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Lacking much of the sarcastic edge found throughout Pixar's hits, we're able to appreciate the naive optimism that endears Seuss' creations to us, without looking for a rotten ironic core.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the portrait first-time director Wendy Keys paints of the 80-year-old is more about myth building than anything else.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: To cram so much complicated history and politics -- not to mention unwavering admiration for a controversial figure such as Chávez -- into a slight documentary is egregious.

Shulman is such an interesting character due to the influence he wielded in Modern architecture's ability to flourish in America that all the gushy conversations with architects and academics actually seem merited.
movie_title: Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The focus could have been refined and made for a simpler tale. As is, it's a thrilling ride -- as long as you don't try to dig too deep into the narrative structure.
Ultimately, the tale is inspiring: Why can't we all be like the Vogels and become great collectors?
Delivers plenty of scares, wince-inducing scenes and indie-film stylistic fillips.

This is fun action sleaze from the classic era of drive-in blaxploitation films, driven by the no-nonsense direction of Jack Hill, and did well enough at the box office to help put the still-gorgeous Pam Grier on the map. Don't miss it.
A chilling study of loneliness and an acting tour de force for Price as the last survivor of a dead race, and not exactly the feel-good movie of 1964.
It's worth seeing just for the sheer jaw-dropping amazement of it all.
Maloof and co-director Charlie Siskel peel back her layers, allowing us to see where her creative universe came from, how she functioned, what she made.

The faithful will devour it, but everyone else will wonder why it takes a dozen band members (including a horn section), copious shots of Kenny's bulging biceps, and not one, not two, but 3-Ds to give shape to these tunes.

Has no one else found it highly peculiar that damn near everybody's choice for the best movie of (let's say) the decade should be dedicated, inferentially but absolutely, to the proposition that Courage is Madness and Cowardice is Best?
movie_title: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)

movie_review_blurb: With its paucity of special effects, umpteen changes in film stock and deliberate pacing, Solaris upends sci-fi's propensity for making a fetish of technology.
Rather than script a dark send-up of our modern take on narcissism -- a Dr. Strangelove of celebrity, Niccol is tentative, making for an uneven satire.
Uneven... The pace can be kinetic, even frantic, or as glacial as a Tarkovsky meditation.
It is the casting of Naomi Watts as Rebecca Yoder that makes the film a singular affair.
Cardoso has done right in her precise and unsentimental direction of a screenplay based on Josefina Lopez's autobiographical play.

Michael Keaton gives his most taut performance since an uncredited turn in Out of Sight and Helena Bonham-Carter has split the difference between her Merchant Ivory days and her desolate Marla in David Fincher's Fight Club.
What could have been heartfelt feels contrived and manipulative.
The awkward set-up finally gives way to a portrait of a family of two, who are at last there for one another.
A riveting literary adventure.

It's Pine that keeps the whole thing afloat, and he manages, astonishingly, to make even the clunkiest, cheesiest lines work, almost transforming the film's chocolate-box sentiments into something honest.

A moving affair, presenting a family unit in all its messy, loving wonder, and the surreality of the situation escalates inexorably into something quietly horrifying. Beautifully shot and played, Home is something of a gem.

At its core, underneath the swashbuckling adventure, Tinker Bell and the Pirate Fairy is a thoughtful tale of female friendship, of appreciating individuality, opening one's mind to new possibilities and always believing in second chances.
A tale of innocence and companionship that is thankfully nowhere near as traumatic as Old Yeller.

The picture anesthetises you into boredom with its inflated sense of purpose, missing an opportunity, whether as a biopic or an artistic drama, to both honour Kelly's memory and entertain modern audiences.

Sentimental reflections on an inspirational teacher are often the makings of weak dishwater films, but in James Clavell's To Sir, with Love, a strong cast and an unforgettable title song make this an undeniable classic.
It's hard to know what came first: Upton or the bad role.
The Lunchbox is the kind of picture that envelopes you like a warm blanket, charming you with its slow-building affection and life-altering curries.
Whether you consider it a smart thriller or a paint-by-numbers spy caper, The Bourne Identity is a dynamic interpretation of Robert Ludlum's bestselling novel.
There's no depth to what you see on screen here: MacFarlane is simply doing what he does best; delivering cheap laughs as he continues to try and push the boundaries.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a refreshing approach to the genre, even when revisiting years later, in an era inundated with superhero movies where each tries to better the last's visual effects budget.

Tris is no Katniss Everdeen, and Divergent is a better film for not trying to impersonate a similar trilogy. It won't excite the world to the extent of The Hunger Games but this more humble offering is nevertheless exciting, fun and satisfying.

The Missing Picture is a haunting and sobering documentary that not only mesmerises with its narrative but also impresses with its collage of techniques that merge seamlessly to give us something truly unique on screen.
Ginger and Rosa is a small flick that reminds audiences how exciting it is to see raw and sincere performances despite what kind of package they're delivered in
The picture is high energy, feel-good, and sweet like bubblegum, and that's perfectly okay.
Ultimately grimy, both in subject matter and visually, thanks to set designers Jim Clay and Geoffrey Kirkland), the picture is frightening and powerful.
The movie stands out for all of the right reasons. It's a breath of fresh air, especially within the Australian industry, and not just because of its unique approach to shooting.
A manic and funny, if ultimately frustrating, sequel.
Could a genuinely good, or genuinely funny, movie ever be made about two girls who operate a phone-sex line?
Wanderlust may fail as satire, but its absurdist slant and eye for detail sustain it through its cruder passages.
Most visibly, Sleepwalk is a story of inter-textual synchronicity, of ideas and gestures bleeding from one medium to another, from book to film, from film to life, and then back again.
The film is ultimately winning because of its devilish anarchic streak, aiming its arrows at the stuffiness of the traditional musical establishment.
It traffics in broad feeling and fluff, but despite the familiarity of its themes, manages to not turn cloying.
The film takes on high-concept ideas that it can't sustain, and which only make its other problems more obvious.
While the film positions itself as an attack on Latin American traditions of misogyny and homophobia, any whiff of a reasonable argument is lost in the disordered muddle it stirs up.

Plunging below the grass line to capture a miniature world in precise detail, The Secret World of Arrietty offers exactly what its title promises, unveiling this secret milieu through thoroughly meticulous animation.
The film is continuously in danger of feeling either too cute or too abrasive, but Alverson pulls it off, incorporating a few surprisingly tender scenes in the process.
Winding up the tension to an almost stubborn degree, Ti West forestalls the inevitable disappointment of its release, a blow that's further softened by how immaculately the whole movie is shot.

Like many of Varda's similarly themed explorations, the results are more than they initially seem, casual anthropology with a strongly humanist bent, resulting in a film that's fueled more by compassion than curiosity.
Where Spielberg has made WWII a venue for his sanctimonious side, a platform to convince viewers that war is indeed hell, Lucas is still in a state of pre-adolescent fascination with the conflict.
A lot of evil is laid on the table in El Sicario, and the film makes a big, if exquisitely subtle show, of theorizing that there's no way to explain how it got there.
Linklater's sense of this place is clearly genuine, and at times it feels like he's using up a lifetime of overheard gems.
A concert film as long-form music video, Vincent Morisset's Inni has style to burn but little apparent focus, flitting about its subject like a buzzing fly.
Equally indebted to Martin Scorsese, Guy Ritchie, and Giorgio Armani, London Boulevard represents the apotheosis of style over substance.
Killing Bono never really gets going, mostly because it has no real idea of how to convey joy, pain, or any type of emotional progression.

As the old, apocryphal quote goes: "Every generation thinks they invented sex." The same can likely be said for the kind of ersatz rebellion celebrated in The Other F Word, a lightweight, frustratingly lazy documentary about punk-rock dads.
The Thing maintains a sideline interest in suspense but no real devotion to prolonging it.
Joe Carnahan's film largely works, building toward a great ending, which functions as one of the best, truest action climaxes in recent memory.
Loose, shaggy, and more than a little rough.
Like that opening sex scene, presented just muddily enough to seem both slightly lurid and tastefully grave, Elles comes off as equally simplistic and indistinct.
The film refuses to focus on its core story, hedging its bets with forays into family drama, environmental thriller, and corporate intrigue.
It runs a complicated bait and switch on its audience, passing ostensible exploitation fodder through a high-toned prestige filter.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Hong Sang-soo hits the beach once again in his latest project, another austerely amusing study of hopeless neurotics making a mockery of leisure.
The whole thing comes out feeling kind of featureless, beaten flat by its own sense of fairness.
Ursula Meier's film is sustained by a sturdy emotional engine and some intrepidly thoughtful characterization.
Plays out as a city-mouse rejoinder to the rustic, open-air daydream of Certified Copy, a snarl of thorny free jazz to that film's graceful aria.
While Steve James's doc is persuasive on an informational level, it doesn't do enough to explore the human side of its subject matter.
Detropia seems to be looking for answers, but the ones it finds are too close to the surface to be satisfying.
Lawless may be full of half-hearted overtures toward depth and emotional complexity, but the film's prestige sheen is mostly a sham; the real focus here is the irrepressible lure of bad behavior.
Beneath its constant comic tangents, The Oyster Princess is also a movie about transition.
Ultimately crammed at a frustrating juncture between period-piece froth and seriously conceived drama, never tipping its hand toward either.
Control is the operative element in Benoît Jacquot's work, with the main caveat being that when someone has it, someone else does not.

While his classic hyperbolic visual style is back in force, Stone can't bother to muster any of his usual righteous anger, instead mischanneling his discontent into a kind of zen acceptance of these perpetually tiresome main characters.
More focused on emotion than adventure, it teases out the possibilities and perils of time travel without embroiling itself in the confusion inherent to the subject.
Unfortunately, there's little sympathy granted to these people, and the revelation of their hidden vices comes across like an increasingly mean series of punchlines.
While Nobody Else But You aspires to a kind of French Fargo, it forgets the primary qualities that made that film work.
Polisse has been compared to The Wire, but beyond a shared interest in the Sisyphean nature of police work, the two are mostly comparable as inverses of each other
While the director does make overtures in the wrong directions, he usually seems to know where to steer his material.

There's great potential for the kind of issues that are taken on, but nothing is resolved, and the biggest questions, of guilt and shame, the gulf of understanding between the first world and the third, remain unengaged.
Fervently passionate and formally meticulous, the latest stunning coup for a director who's made a career of repurposing archetypal storylines.
Art History stands out as one of Joe Swanberg's most visually and conceptually accomplished experiments.
Troubadours gets off on vague talk about community and a generous helping of tunes.
If Sound It Out never really digs its claws into its material, it at least approaches it with a careful level of thought and commitment.
The Sleeping Beauty both qualifies and clarifies that previous film, expanding upon the director's usual preoccupations within a dreamily ambiguous storybook world.
So much is contained in the film, from real technical virtuosity to heart-wrenching moments of pathos, that it's a shame it seems satisfied to be so ordinary in other aspects.
This is a strident issue movie with the feel of a more objective portrayal.
A delirious representation of incipient personalities in bloom, its form as amorphous and reckless as the vibrant youths it portrays.
As good as it is at times, The Other Woman never nears greatness; it lacks the mettle and focus to push beyond well-groomed melodrama.
The film sets off coarse jokes like signal flares, positioned to distract from its otherwise dowdy makeup.
The elevation of the family from middle-class strivers to stratospherically wealthy jerks removes any trace of political specificity, but also elevates it to the chilly realm of the fairy tale.
A distressing portrayal of how basically good people can be affected by adverse circumstances.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sergei Eisenstein's masterpiece is a persistently political work salvaged by its unforgettable grasp of motion.
Like Crash without the clunky characterization, Rabbit Hole is film as medicine, a big, pretty pill to be uncomfortably swallowed.
In this Riviera vacation atmosphere, all sun, sand, and skin, the dialectic of opposites the film attempts to enforce instead melts down to little more than kinky foreplay.
The first film to confront the ghosts of government collaboration in communist Czechoslovakia may be new for Czechs, but otherwise it's a familiar invocation of a problematically buried past.
Is Godard the prostitute or the pimp?
movie_title: Every Man for Himself (Sauve qui peut (la vie)) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: It's a little crude to see the character's weirdness being exploited for drama after so readily being jabbed for cheap laughs in the first half
The film heaps on events and obstacles far too liberally for its skimpy frame.
Of the million potential roads a documentary can take, the narrow, intimate route explored in Strange Powers seems like one of the least economical.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, Carmo, Hit the Road suffers from an inability to decide what it wants to present.
As Good As Dead is a crude externalization of xenophobic fears shaped, at least for a while, into a halfway decent thriller.
Collaborations between Robert De Niro and Edward Norton--one generation's most respected actor paired with another's most affected--seem doomed to be defined by acting with a capital A.
Deep in the Woods opens with a flurry of coarse, increasingly brutal activity, seemingly as caught up in its own tumbling progression as it expects its audience to be.
movie_title: Au fond des bois (Deep in the Woods) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sound It Out is content to exist as a modest portrait of a store that offers not only largely obsolete collectors' items, but also the resolute glimmer of human contact.
You'll undoubtedly feel something when watching a film like this, but not necessarily anything that hasn't been evoked more originally, and more effectively, elsewhere.
Wuershang is too busy mixing up a slurry of postmodern techniques, abortive fight scenes, and noisy set pieces to spend any time on fundamentals.
movie_title: The Butcher, The Chef And The Swordsman (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One reason why The Inheritors works is that it abandons the reckless point-and-shoot aesthetic of so many social-issue movies.
A portrait of a town that never feels completely real, devoid of normality or everyday activity, a depiction which undercuts the eventual emotional escalation.
Yet another movie about a blinkered man-child reaching the limits of his extended childhood, True Adolescents seems as lazy and mush-brained as its central character.
The documentary glosses over practical concerns, instead choosing mute reverence for the magisterial Ferran Adrià and his bizarre methods.
A resolutely small parable of grief that often feels menaced by its big-idea concept.
The film eventually reveals itself as a specific appreciation of a job done well, rather than a rosy-eyed celebration.
A portrait of female fidelity that ranges across centuries and social classes, Snow Flower and the Secret Fan is sad, sumptuous fluff with a refined literary pedigree.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that sincerely believes that it's crafting a thoughtful debate on the conflict between faith and reason.
The Perfect Host is really a game without any rules, one where characters and situations exist in total thrall of the next shocking twist.
Succeeds by perfectly recapturing the way teenagers behave, the forced pretense of their actions, their deadly seriousness in dramatizing what amounts to minor emotional damage.
We Are the Night's primary interest seems to be wish fulfillment, but it's hard to tell at times exactly whose fantasies these are supposed to be.
It's always refreshing to see a newcomer with so much energy, but the chaos that takes over Cost of a Soul ultimately feels wasteful.
Opting for craziness over coherence, True Legend at least expends its energy in the right place.
The latest (and by far most sneaky) attempt to slip one of its wrestlers into multiplexes, WWE Films' That's What I Am is surprisingly low on testosterone.
Morgan Spurlock sets out to fund his movie about product placement entirely through product placement, turning the entire film into the story of its own creation.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Giuseppe Capotondi at least keeps a strong rein over the proceedings, preventing any direct slides into silliness.
If this version fails, it's at least partially because it's been sent on the cinematic equivalent of a suicide mission.
The nicest thing to be said about Cat Run might be that it doesn't know what kind of movie it wants to become.
The film draws its laughs from the suffering of its characters, knocking them against each other while jury-rigging a spindly plot from their in-fighting.
That rare documentary that's as thrilling as art as it is as reportage, a marvelously shaped thesis that's both disquieting and humbling.
Matteo Garrone has a sure eye for outlandish set pieces that exhibit the expansive outlines of his ideas, but these spectacles are sporadic, and the spaces between them tend to lag.
The film thrives on ambiguity, keeping all things blurry outside its main character's focused perspective, its myopia sustained by Luminița Gheorghiu's tough, quietly intense performance.
Now a 20-year-old antique slapped with a superfluous 3D transfer, Jurassic Park still has the power to amaze.
The film's black humor is inextricably tied to serious questions about moral relativism and personal responsibility.
A definitive reflection on the work of two great directors and the specific slices of cinema they so fruitfully cultivated.
movie_title: How to Smell a Rose: A Visit with Ricky Leacock at his Farm in Normandy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It does well in using dialogue to shape its escalating tête-à-tête, but the filmmaking is too fuzzy to expand on those ideas.
It confirms the Roy Andersson universe as one of near-fossilized similitude, in which any effort or movement is disruptive, revealing new cracks in the set illusion of order.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of real analysis or consideration leaves this perilously close to a Goldilocks-style depiction of privileged female indecision.
The film's worst quality is its underhanded attempt to convey a complex recounting of one family's ordeal while fudging all the pertinent details.
The film is content to drift free-associatively through a tangle of linked relationships, considering the intricacies of group mechanics via an expressive free-form structure.
It affects a general air of artistically inclined realism, but it's mostly concerned with building tension via a steady accumulation of flatly conceived misery.
The film carves out a rich emotional sphere concomitant to its stunning production design, finding delicate poetry in the dispassionate pursuit of revenge.
It settles firmly into the perspective of a lost soul who finds solace in the swaddling security of fantasy.
Michael Mann's camera elegantly collapses the spaces between bodies and objects without sacrificing spatial coherence.
A chronicle the act of labor as both a universal function of life and a spectacle in itself.
Nuri Bilge Ceylan again exhibits his gift for making interesting stories out of predetermined plots, locating small eddies of change in the midst of eternally fixed dynamics.
Refusing to mourn anything, displaying a Futurist-style disdain for the past, Sion Sono imagines a world in which static adherence to old ideas leads directly to doom.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film itself is a lumbering tank of a movie, chunky, loud, and clumsy, mulching down men into meat as proof of its dramatic seriousness and gloomy worldview.
The lack of tangible dramatic follow-through leaves the film feeling incomplete, indistinguishable from so much other undercooked festival fare.
With its optimistic ending, the film muddies its previous statements regarding the danger of unthinkingly hanging on to totems of the past.
Pascale Ferran's film isn't daring enough to fully embrace the narrative fragmentation that it sporadically assumes.
The film achieves nothing more than hollow caricature, too caught up in dumb dress-up pageantry to accomplish anything else.
The film remains too pallid and diffuse, the development of its mood and characters suffering as a result.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the defeated tone of Patricio Guzmán's tales, a spotlight is placed on the power of persistence.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: By modeling its structure so closely after All the President's Men, Spotlight only draws closer attention to its lack of scope and ambition.
A diffident, occasionally sly comedy that could have benefitted from a little more energy and range.
It proves that Mekas is still very much awake, contemplating the broad gulfs of the past and future, the little life that, as Shakespeare put it, "is rounded with a sleep."
This is a heartfelt essay film that digs into several instances of trauma occasioned by Mexico's drug war.
The film is caught somewhere between freeform sketch comedy, gonzo documentary, and irony-soaked Warholian melodrama.
Ben Wheatley's film reduces the modus operandi of the action movie down to its starkest elements.
The limitations of black and white both point to Philippe Garrel's silent-era influences and identify a way forward.
Martin Scorsese crafts a versatile, multifaceted work that encourages serious reflection and contemplation.
Tom Ford remains too reliant on overwrought imagery, residual prestige affectations, and conventional rhythms to break free of either genre the film experiments with.
Paul Schrader's film scrambles for contemporary relevance and finds only nihilistic hollowness.
Pedro Almodóvar's object-oriented approach ends up blocking off the deeper emotional access that Alice Munro's stories so effortlessly attain.
Director Craig Atkinson's film explicates its points with blunt but persuasive efficiency.
Chad Hartigan's film is especially perceptive about the effect of external influence on personal development.
The film's primary effect is to substantiate gossip, while satisfying the perverse human desire to gander at misery.
Andrzej Zulawski's film experiment ranks somewhere between captivatingly off the wall and utterly exhausting.
Jacques Audiard's film struggles to overcome the burden of its over-simplified, moralizing setup.
Louder Than Bombs is a parable that takes depression seriously as a condition and a state of being.
The reworking of a tired horror trope into a transformed feminist symbol stands out as an impressive act of genre revisionism.
As in Nathan Silver's previous work, what could have been a rote retread of Pasolini's Teorema blossoms into a study of factional identity and power dynamics.
It confronts the hard realities of a world in which few make it to maturity without their share of scars, and no one makes it out of adulthood alive.
By eschewing even basic B-roll footage, it ends up feeling even more stripped down than Frederick Wiseman's patient inquisitions, yet nearly as complex overall.
Ira Sachs's push for heartrending poetry makes it clear that the film is putting too fine a gloss on the acute pains of one small tragedy.
Anton Corbijn constructs a stifling world of shadowy surveillance and intersecting national interests, building on John Le Carré's sense of moral and emotional exhaustion.
Michel Gondry bungles his adaptation of the Boris Vian novel by indulging in homespun craftwork at the expense of plot and character detail.
Conventional but never sanctimonious, it balances out its familiar recovery angle with a healthy measure of sardonic wit.
Conditioning the audience to find dread in every seemingly innocent gesture, the film turns even the simplest touch between family members into something tinged with menace.
Seems to struggle in making its interesting ideas apparent, leaving them stranded beneath the dry surface of an otherwise ordinary procedural.
The songs performed here function as the creative end point of emotional trauma, revealing pain gradually transfigured into art.

A work like this serves to remind us of the shining beacons Miyazaki's left behind him, the testaments to pursuing beauty in the face of so much ugliness, themselves lasting reminders of the quiet rewards of determination.
Despite the grim fatalism of these characters, the focus is less on universal questions of mortality than the lengthening shadows cast by the passage of time.
movie_title: Nugu-ui ttal-do anin Haewon (Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A film whose only distinguishing characteristic is how big a mess it makes of its already meager ambitions.
Less precise and cohesive than much of Joe Swanberg's recent work, as its small, improvisational skeleton struggles to meet the demands of the more ambitious story it's trying to tell.
It takes the basic form of the revenge flick and dips it in tar, making for a movie that comes out sticky, nasty, and black.
A movie which sits at the nexus between spoken and written language, the latter mostly of the programming variety.

Short Circuit 3 is the sort of kid-friendly, mass-audience-seeking movie that, if released today, would have tried to play off its shortcomings with ironic distance, noisy clatter and special effects.
There's so much baggage involved in the kind of dilettantish games Jamie and Crystal are playing that it's a shame that the film never fully engages with these enticing issues.
Jem Cohen's film finds its most salient tension in the fraught relationship between known and unknown objects.
It's disheartening that, despite some half-hearted overtures toward shifting the comedy paradigm, the filmmakers make little attempt to expand their comedic palette.
This sardonic depiction of Britain, as a land where a thin veneer of strained politesse and fussy specificity of tastes masks a throbbing heart of darkness, makes for Ben Wheatley's best film yet.
These films have always been about the power of words, their ability to bridge gulfs of time and space, the thrill of ideas and opinions taking definitive shape.

More than anything, Alberi is about the essential significance of nature, the way it provides not only the physical necessities for life, but the overarching structure for all its systems and processes.
An effective bit of human drama, competently, and sometimes movingly, telling a story that deserves to be told.
While Atiq Rahimi's film may peel away the many layers of its female lead like an onion, the end result is still just an onion.
A human-interest story that claims spite for human-interest stories, the film has some pretty divisive issues at its core that leave it torn between contrasting approaches.
It doesn't seem to have any pretensions beyond the regimented unveiling of a parade of odd occurrences, plodding along under the banner of absurdity.
Approaching his lifestyle with ambivalence, the film still accords Jules enormous respect, showing an almost holy appreciation for the beautiful process of his blacksmithing work.
Formally ostentatious and unrepentantly messy, the film manages to implicitly convey the overdriven, coked-up confusion that many '70s period pieces make painfully overt.
The next step in Jafar Panahi's personal cinema of captivity, a fully fictionalized, wildly bewildering work which imagines a man at war with his own creative impulse.
What results is chaotic but ultimately focused, bound by an intense devotion to disassembling genre and narrative standards.
The film puts too many elements into play, which means it ends up darting hopelessly between a series of underdeveloped storylines.
It defines Manoel de Oliveira's late period, during which his movies have continued to shrink in size and scope while remaining thematically expansive.

It presents little that wasn't already done better in Myth of the American Sleepover, an equally evocative tale of longing that was far more successful at matching teen tropes with atmospheric naturalism.
After years of respectable filmmaking, it's refreshing to witness a reinvigorated Roman Polanski willing to once again delve deep into seedy psychodrama.
Like Michael Cera's two recent films with Sebastian Silva, Night Moves reveals the dark core contained within an actor's nice-guy neuroticism.
By reducing its principals to stock figures in an extended chess game, it ends up providing steady, neatly staged thrills, but little else of substance.
In the end, it reduces public-housing dwellers to the same stock roles they occupy in less thoughtful films, limiting their stories rather than allowing them to develop.
Despite an undeniable attraction to the majestic, Aleksandr Sokurov seems equally adverse to straightforward spectacle, approaching potentially colossal subjects from odd, specific angles.
It's all showy viscera, no ballet, and wan attempts at the gravity of something like Drug War.
